resource.name: Police Active Warrants
resource.description:
This dataset represents all active warrants recorded by the Norfolk Police Department. Warrants can be searched by type of crime, demographics of persons involved and total number of outstanding warrants.  This dataset is updated daily.  

Note: this dataset does not contain any active warrants that could possibly:
•	jeopardize an ongoing investigation, or prosecution, or the safety of an individual, 
•	cause a suspect to flee or evade detection,
•	result in the destruction of evidence.

resource.name: Permits and Inspections
resource.description: This dataset provides information about permits and their associated inspections, violations, and status information. Norfolk’s Development Service Center (DSC) issues building, plumbing, mechanical, electrical, fire, amusement, elevator, certificates of occupancy, and zoning permits.  The purpose of the DSC is to consolidate acquisition of permits to one central location within Norfolk City Hall for the convenience of customers. This dataset is updated daily.
resource.attribution: Phil Winslow; Codes Enforcement Team Lead, Department of City Planning

resource.name: Neighborhood Quality Code Enforcement Cases
resource.description: This dataset provides data from the Norfolk Division of Neighborhood Quality’s code enforcement cases including associated inspections, violations and status.  The mission of the Division of Neighborhood Quality is to maintain and strengthen neighborhood standards. Staff use a variety of tools to achieve compliance including educating civic leagues, residents and the public about neighborhood quality.  Other tools include working with homeowners to establish timelines for projects or pursuing legal steps for abatement. This data reflects the workflow of a responsive customer-oriented organization.
resource.attribution: Sherry Johnson - Neighborhood Quality Division - Department of Neighborhood Development

resource.name: MyNorfolk
resource.description:
This dataset provides data from MyNorfolk, a citizen services portal that delegates and tracks requests and questions about the city of Norfolk and the services we provide to our residents, businesses, and visitors.  Data for the service requests is collected from phone calls, emails, an app for smart phones and on-line. The portal is managed by the Norfolk Cares Center; its mission is to provide a single point of contact for visitors, residents, businesses and city staff to request a city service, report a concern, seek information about Norfolk, or follow-up on a previous request for service.

**Disclaimer - With the current process in place, not all tickets are closed automatically. There could be tickets shown as open in this dataset that are closed in our other systems. We are working to address the issue.
resource.attribution: Halima Akar, Customer Service Manager, Norfolk Cares Center
columns_description: Department/Division Responsible for Completion of Service Request
Date and Time of last update made to service request
Current Status of Service Request
Address of Service Request Concern
Service Request Identification Number
Date and Time Record was created
Service Request Issue

resource.name: Litter Index
resource.description:
The Community Appearance Index, also known as the Litter Index, is a tool designed by Keep America Beautiful to visually evaluate the overall appearance of a community using litter as an indicator. Every year, 60 routes throughout the five wards of Norfolk are analyzed to determine the cleanliness of the city. After a thorough training, a team of volunteers conduct the analysis using a scoring system ranging from 1-4 with “1” indicating minimal to no litter and “4” indicating extremely littered. Methodology for this process includes recruiting volunteers who commit to attend a one-and-a-half-day Community Appearance Index scan. Each volunteer is thoroughly trained on the index to accurately and consistently survey a statistical sample of the city. The results of the scan are then averaged to produce the City of Norfolk Community Appearance Index score.

This dataset is updated annually; the data begins in 2010.  The Litter Index survey is normally conducted in August; the 2020 survey will be delayed due to COVID-19.

resource.name: Emergency Communications 24-Hour Call Volume
resource.description:
This dataset shows all calls processed by emergency communications personnel in Norfolk, VA. The Emergency Communications Center is where calls are received from the public and then dispatched to public safety personnel (police, fire-rescue). The dataset shows daily (24-hour period of operations) calls and texts processed by emergency communications personnel. This dataset will be updated daily.

Please note: Data from April 5, 2023 to May 23, 2023 will not available due to equipment upgrades during this timeframe.
resource.attribution: Department of Emergency Preparedness and Response - Division of Emergency Communications

resource.name: Norfolk Cares Center
resource.description:
As of October 30, 2019, this data set will no longer be updated.  A new citizen request app, called MyNorfolk, has been implemented and data from that app is available in this Open Data portal. 

The Norfolk Cares data set provides data from the IMPACT System. The data was collected by phone calls, emails, iPhone requests, and on-line requests.  This data set includes service requests from November 2014 to October 2019.

resource.name: Property Assessment and Sales - FY20
resource.description: This dataset represents real estate assessment and sales data that is updated on a quarterly basis by the Real Estate Assessor’s Office. This dataset contains information for properties in the city including: Acreage, Square footage, GPIN, Street Address, year built, current land value, current improvement values, and current total value. The information is obtained from Real Estate Assessor’s Office ProVal records database.

resource.name: Norfolk 2020 American Community Survey Five-Year Estimates
resource.description:
This dataset contains the American Community Survey (ACS) five-year estimates for Norfolk, Virginia. According to the United States Census Bureau, the ACS is the premier source for detailed population and housing information about communities and the nation. Every year, the Census Bureau conducts a survey and creates estimates for demographic categories such as income, employment, poverty, race, ethnicity, housing, age, gender, internet access, vehicle access, and other topics. For census tracts, 5-year estimates are generated and released to the public. 
This dataset includes five-year estimates released in 2020 for census tracts in Norfolk, VA and will be updated annually with each new release of five-year estimates.

resource.name: Resident Survey 2022
resource.description:
The City of Norfolk is committed to using data to help inform decisions and allocate resources. One important source of data is input from residents about their priorities and satisfaction with the services we provide. Norfolk last conducted a citywide survey of residents in 2014.

To provide up-to-date information regarding resident priorities and satisfaction, Norfolk contracted with ETC institute to conduct a survey of residents. This survey was conducted in the fall of 2022; surveys were sent via the U.S. Postal Service and respondents were given the choice of responding by mail, online, or by telephone. This survey represents a random and statistically valid sample of residents from across the city. ETC Institute monitored responses and followed up to ensure all sections of the city were represented. An opportunity was also provided for residents not included in the random sample to take the survey and express their views. This dataset includes all survey data, excluding demographic data to protect privacy. This dataset will be updated every two years.
columns_description: The number of responses, grouped by Response Method, Random Sample Survey, Ward, Superward, Question Category, Question, and Response.

Indicates if the survey respondent responded via mail or web.
The Superward that the survey respondent lived in at the time of the survey.
The Ward that the survey respondent lived in at the time of the survey.
The survey response.

resource.name: FEMA NFIP Claims
resource.description:
First, a caveat: the NFIP data does NOT provide information specific to individual homes or parcels. This information is protected under federal law. All personal identifying information about policy holders has been redacted, and data has been anonymized to census tract, reported ZIP code, and one decimal point digit of latitute and longitude. If mapped, flood insurance policies and claims may appear to be clustered at a particular location due to this anonymization.
What all that means: you cannot search for an address to see whether it has flooded.
However, among many things, this data shows flooding trends in Norfolk over the last 40+ years. It shows the census tracts that flood most frequently. And it shows where the largest number and highest value of claims occur.

FEMA believes this historic release of NFIP data promotes transparency, reduces complexity related to public data requests, and improves how stakeholders interact with and understand the program. This is the largest, most comprehensive release of NFIP data coordinated by FEMA to date. This dataset allows for customizable searches to create reports, analyze and visualize present and historical NFIP data faster and easier than before. 
This data will help FEMA build a national culture of preparedness by providing claims and policy information people need to make better choices about their flood risk and the insurance they need to protect the life they've built. 
Norfolk's Open Data team extracted city-specific information from the FEMA dataset. The dataset included here represents almost 6,000 claims on record from 1977 through 2019, totaling 67 million dollars in damage in the City of Norfolk.

resource.name: Streetlight Upgrade Project
resource.description: Information regarding Dominion Energy owned (city leased) streetlights that are designated for upgrades to LED bulbs, to improve dependability, light emission, reduce energy consumption, and improve nighttime public safety. The prioritization of the upgrades was determined using public safety information including calls for service and traffic accidents, as well as vehicular and pedestrian traffic levels.

resource.name: Tree Planting Program
resource.description: Recreation, Parks and Open Space’s Bureau of Parks and Urban Forestry plants hundreds of trees each year along city streets, within city parks, and on other city properties.  This dataset gives pertinent tree species information, shows important geographic information about which parts of Norfolk are receiving trees in a given year, and historical data about planting date.  City staff utilizes Microsoft excel to track tree planting information. This dataset will show where the City of Norfolk plants its trees on city owned properties.  This data is updated annually.
resource.attribution: Steven Traylor, City Forester; Parks and Forestry Operations, Recreation, Parks and Open Spaces

resource.name: Norfolk Animal Care and Adoption Center (NACC)
resource.description: The Norfolk Animal Care and Adoption Center (NACC) is the city’s animal sheltering facility. The NACC is an open-admission shelter; animals are never turned away, regardless of species, age, health or temperament.  This data reports on an animal from the moment it arrives at the shelter (intake) to the moment it leaves (outcome).  It also reports on foster activities.  This data is updated monthly.
resource.attribution: Ramon Villatoro; Assistant Animal Services Supervisor, General Services – Norfolk Animal Care and Adoption Center

resource.name: Adoptions
resource.description:
This dataset contains demographic and case characteristics of children in foster care in Norfolk with the goal of adoption.  The dataset includes the sex, age, race, placement, parental rights status and adoption status of these children. The data is from Virginia’s Online Automated Services Information System (OASIS).  OASIS is a comprehensive system that tracks the day-to-day activities performed by social workers statewide and is the official case record system for foster care and adoption cases in Virginia.  

This dataset details the work accomplished by staff at the Norfolk Department of Human Services with the goal of finding safe, permanent homes for children in Norfolk’s foster care system. This dataset is updated monthly.
resource.attribution: Deanna Powell-Brickhouse, Department of Human Services

resource.name: Employee Demographics
resource.description: This dataset provides demographic information about City of Norfolk employees. The data is provided by Norfolk's Department of Human Resources and is updated daily.
resource.attribution: Ramona Benson, Department of Human Resources
columns_description: Gender identification of the employee.
Starting year of work with the City of Norfolk for the employee.
Title of the job identified.
Race/Ethnicity identification of the employee.
City in which the employee officially resides.
If applicable, the specific division, bureau, or unit an employee is in within the department.
If the employee served in the military and the status of that service.
Birth year of the City of Norfolk employee.
Identification of the department name.
Highest level of education reported.

resource.name: Fleet
resource.description:
This dataset provides data about the assets that are managed by the Division of Fleet Management.  Assets fall into two categories: vehicle or equipment.  

Fleet Management uses a point system that considers a variety of factors to determine which assets are recommended for replacement.   An asset with 15 points or higher is recommended for replacement.
resource.attribution: Tanisha Brown, Fleet Management, Department of General Services

resource.name: Mental Health, Intellectual/Developmental Disabilities, and Substance Use Disorder Services
resource.description:
Norfolk Community Services Board (CSB) is the primary provider of public mental health, substance abuse, intellectual /developmental disabilities and substance use disorder in Norfolk, VA.  The continuum of services provided by the CSB spans from outreach and prevention through intensive psychiatric care.  CSB services are provided by clinical service professionals with expertise in these service areas.

This dataset is a monthly breakdown of certain services that CSB provides Norfolk’s residents. These services include mental health, developmental, substance abuse, and emergency services. These services do not make up all the services that CSB provides, that include services such as infant and toddler and specific grant-funded services. A total hourly duration for the month is provided, as well as details on the type of service that was provided. This dataset will be updated monthly.
columns_description: Denotes if a service was a direct service (face-to-face service with a client) or a client related service (any service associated with a specific client, such as treatment planning or reaching out to a client’s provider).

Denotes if the area of care was a mental health service, developmental service, emergency or ancillary service, or a substance use disorder service. An individual may be provided with multiple service areas, but only one is listed per client as part of the monthly aggregation.
City of Norfolk cost center code for financial tracking of the CSB program providing the service. This data does not include any special revenue accounts.
Month and year that the service was provided.
The general description/categorization of the service provided by Community Services Board (CSB).
Total duration (in hours) during the month of the service provided. This data only includes services that track in hours.

resource.name: Micromobility (Electric Scooters and Bikes)
resource.description: This dataset is data about trips on electric scooters and electric-assisted bikes. Lime scooters were made available to the public in June 2019 to use throughout Norfolk, and Lime e-bikes were made available to the public in June 2021. Data represents trips from July 2019 to the present and is updated weekly.
columns_description: Type of vehicle used
Duration of the trip in minutes
Distance of the trip in miles
Date trip started (EST)
Hour trip started (EST)
Date trip ended (EST)
Hour trip ended (EST)
Census tract where trip began
Census tract where trip ended

resource.name: Bike and Pedestrian Trip Counts
resource.description:
Bike and pedestrian counters have been installed at six locations along the Elizabeth River Trail and at 15 locations along Norfolk’s existing bike lanes to accurately track pedestrian and cyclist use along the trail and bike network. This counter system combines the passive infrared sensor to count pedestrians on the adjacent sidewalk and an inductive loop sensor to detect bicycles in existing bike lanes. This dataset comprises data from two types of counters – Eco-Counter and Roadsys. The Eco-Counter data begins in April 2019 and is updated weekly. The Roadsys data begins in April 2021 and is updated quarterly.

Please note: The counters at the following location are currently offline, making up-to-date data from these counters temporarily unavailable:
-	Weyanoke Footbridge – last date August 28, 2019
-	E. Ocean View Avenue – last date April 28, 2021
-	ERT Bridge/Lamberts Point – last date April 28, 2021
-	Jeff Robertson Park (ERT) – last date December 17, 2021
-	Park Ave/Claiborne Ave (ERT) – last date December 19, 2021
We are working to correct this issue as quickly as possible.
columns_description: Date that the counter collected data
Number of pedestrians that passed the counter
Latitude location of the counter
Type of counter
Longitude location of the counter
Number of bikes that passed the counter
Location of the counter

resource.name: Norfolk Master Street List
resource.description: Information containing the master list of valid street names in the City.  Street names may include a directional that is fully spelled out (i.e., East, West, North, or South) depending on how the street name was legally recorded. Those streets with a pre-directional (i.e., N, S, E, W) before the street name will be listed twice in this index, once under the first letter of the street name and again using the pre-direction. For example, W Brambleton Avenue will be listed both under W and under B. Street status field also indicates where a street is located: city, military base, or crosses over both military base and city.
columns_description: Directional word found as last word in the street name and there is no other directional to the right of it.
Directional word found as the first word in the street name and there is no other directional to the left of it.
A component that qualifies the street name by type of street such as AVE(Avenue), DR (Drive), or RD (Road).
The primary name field that identifies the street.  Street names can be words or numbers.
A component that qualifies the street name by type of street such as AVE(Avenue), DR (Drive), or RD (Road).
Full Street Name
Status as to where the Street is located: City, Base, City & Base, Paper, Private.

resource.name: Property Assessment and Sales - FY23
resource.description: This dataset represents real estate assessment and sales data made available by the Office of the Real Estate Assessor. This dataset contains information for properties in the city, including acreage, square footage, GPIN, street address, year built, current land value, current improvement value, and current total value. The information is obtained from the Office of the Real Estate Assessor ProVal records database. This dataset is updated daily on weekdays.
resource.attribution: Norfolk Office of the Real Estate Assessor
columns_description: Most recent assessment year
Street name of the property
The identifier for the house, building or other feature which follows the address number itself, often indicating a unit number; such as 200 Hyde Park Road, Unit 2C.
Document number associated with the most recent sale of the parcel
Approximate area of a commercial building
Most recent assessed total value of the parcel
Street number of the property
Property class code and description
Street direction of the property
Approximate acreage of the parcel
The word that follows the name of a street to further describe that street; for example, London Bridge Road Ext.
Zip code of the property
Land Record Serial Number
Parcel Identification Number
Most recent assessed building value of the parcel
Use type of the parcel
Current owner of the parcel
Label assigned to improvements/buildings located on the parcel.  (Extensions beginning in “R” indicates residential, “C” indicates commercial, “L” indicates land-only)
Most recent sale date of the parcel
City in which the property is located
Approximate square footage of the parcel
Approximate finished living area of the property
Most recent seller/giver of the parcel
Most recent buyer/receiver of the parcel
The legal description of the parcel
Most recent sale price of the parcel
Unit number of the property
Street type of the property
Most recent assessed land value of the parcel
Year built of the primary dwelling on the parcel
Geographic Parcel Identification Number
